qas.question: Where has cross-border policing been most under-studied?
Who compared transnational police information and intelligence sharing practices?
What kind of policing has become common practice?
What problems did Sheptycki say 'organizational pathologies' have caused for police?

answers.text: make the functioning of security-intelligence processes in transnational policing deeply problematic

qas.question: What paradox did Sheptycki point out?

answers.text: the harder policing agencies work to produce security, the greater are feelings of insecurity

qas.question: Where has cross-border policing been least under-studied?
Where has cross-border policing been most over-studied?
What kind of policing has become rare practice?

plausible_answers.text: make the functioning of security-intelligence processes in transnational policing deeply problematic

qas.question: What problems did Sheptycki say 'organizational pathologies' haven't caused for police?

plausible_answers.text: the harder policing agencies work to produce security, the greater are feelings of insecurity

context: Studies of this kind <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>outside of Europe<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> are even rarer, so it is difficult to make generalizations, but one small-scale study that compared transnational police information and intelligence sharing practices at specific cross-border locations in North America and Europe confirmed that low visibility of police information and intelligence sharing was a common feature (<a1_0>Alain<a1_0/>, 2001). <a2_0><b7_0>Intelligence-led<b7_0/><a2_0/> policing is now common practice in most advanced countries (Ratcliffe, 2007) and it is likely that police intelligence sharing and information exchange has a common morphology around the world (Ratcliffe, 2007). James Sheptycki has analyzed the effects of the new information technologies on the organization of policing-intelligence and suggests that a number of 'organizational pathologies' have arisen that <a3_0><b8_0>make the functioning of security-intelligence processes in transnational policing deeply problematic<b8_0/><a3_0/>. He argues that transnational police information circuits help to "compose the panic scenes of the security-control society". The paradoxical effect is that, <a4_0><b9_0>the harder policing agencies work to produce security, the greater are feelings of insecurity<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
